column4: Was there some kind of forced-reboot update today? My home Ubuntu machine was rebooted when I got back from work and, while I was at work, my work Ubuntu machine rebooted *while I was using it*. I window popped up while I was typing a Jabber message and the spacebar "clicked" a button in a dialog box, but I only saw it for a second. Then my whole system went down and rebooted!
You have  the updates to automatiaclly install?
Only set to notify me of updates, not to download or install automatically.
only major updates such as a new kernel need an update
It's wierd, the power didn't go out, I don't know why my home machine would have rebooted on its own, no one else touched it.
Maybe  the power did go out,  but only slightly,  enough for it to re boot,  but not enough for you to notice it going out

Yes, I know kernel updates require reboot, but it doesn't force a reboot even when there's a kernel update. Kinda strange.  Is there a website that keeps track of updates, descriptions, and date/time of release?
don't know
I think someone else had a similar issue not that long ago
Doing stuff on  Ubuntu, and then re boot just like that
I think maybe at least once I have had something like this happen to  my Ubuntu as well
It was probably just some little hardware issue,  that just happended to result in a re boot,  and in that case something that isn't worth worrying about.
Glad to know I'm not going crazy and that it's happened to others :) but a bit alarming, to be sure.
or maybe a bug in Ubuntu that resulted in a re boot
That it happened to two seperate machines in two different cities made me think it was related to an update.
Well, anyway, thanks for your help :) have a good evening.
not the evening anymore in my time zone
np
aah, sorry. :) then have a good next few hours ;)
thanks
Debian Stable is well  stable, meaning a bit behind,   with the kernel and such.   Ubuntu is based on the testing Debian repo and then does it's own changes or something like that.
Aah, okay, thanks for explaining that
Yeah Debain can't even do  Ext4  yet as far as I know,  unless something special is done to it
